A Playful Dive into the Wild World of HunieCam Studio

Rating: ★★★☆☆ (3/5)

HunieCam Studio offers a tongue-in-cheek take on simulation games, injecting a healthy dose of humor and adult-themed content into a genre known for its meticulous management mechanics. As a player who enjoys a mix of strategy and light-hearted entertainment, I ventured into the world of cam studio management with a mix of curiosity and caution.

Set in the fictional world of HuniePop, HunieCam Studio casts you as a manager of aspiring cam girls, each with their own distinct personalities, preferences, and skills. The goal? To rake in as much cash as possible by recruiting, training, and scheduling these virtual models to perform explicit webcam shows and earn followers.

The game's art style leans into a cartoony, exaggerated aesthetic that's quite different from the typical simulation game. The character designs are vibrant and distinctive, though they might not be everyone's cup of tea. The UI is functional but lacks the polished finesse seen in more intricate management titles.

What sets HunieCam Studio apart is its irreverent humor and casual approach to the simulation genre. The game unabashedly embraces its mature content, from quirky dialogues to over-the-top character traits. While this can be entertaining for those who enjoy such humor, it can also be off-putting for players seeking a more serious management experience.

Gameplay revolves around managing your cam girls' schedules, upgrading their skills, and investing in various upgrades to attract more viewers. However, the management mechanics lack depth and complexity, leading to a repetitive cycle that can become monotonous over time. The lack of a deeper strategy element might disappoint players seeking a more engaging challenge.

A notable downside is the lack of character development or meaningful interactions with the cam girls. They remain one-dimensional and solely focused on their virtual careers, which can make it difficult to form any real attachment to them beyond their profitability.

HunieCam Studio offers a casual and often amusing experience that can be a fun distraction for a short while. However, it lacks the depth and strategic complexity that many simulation enthusiasts might be looking for. Its adult-themed content might also limit its appeal to a narrower audience.

In summary, HunieCam Studio offers a light-hearted and cheeky take on the simulation genre, but its shallow mechanics, repetitive gameplay, and one-dimensional characters prevent it from reaching its full potential. If you're looking for a game that combines humor with management mechanics and don't mind the mature content, it might provide a few hours of entertainment. However, for those seeking a more robust and engaging simulation experience, HunieCam Studio might fall short of expectations.

[h1]HunieCam Studio: An Entertaining Management Sim with a Cheeky Twist[/h1]

Introduction:
[h2]HunieCam Studio[/h2] is a unique management simulation game, placing players in charge of a cam studio. Although it features adult-themed elements, this review will focus on the gameplay mechanics, features, and the overall experience, keeping it suitable for a general audience.

Gameplay and Mechanics:
[h2]In HunieCam Studio[/h2], players take on the role of a cam studio manager, where they must recruit and guide a roster of models towards stardom. The gameplay is centered around managing the studio, hiring and training models, scheduling their activities, and striving to earn fans and revenue through various cam shows. As a manager, players are responsible for juggling multiple tasks such as advertising, managing girls' stress levels, and ensuring the studio's reputation grows. This management simulation demands strategic planning and time management to optimize earnings and grow the studio's fan base.

Cheeky Humor and Art Style:
[h2]HunieCam Studio's art style and humor[/h2] provide a light-hearted and tongue-in-cheek approach to the management genre. The game explores adult themes but does so with a playful and humorous tone, making it an enjoyable experience for players who appreciate risqué humor.

Addictive Progression:
[h2]The game's progression system[/h2] is designed to be addictive. Players can unlock new features, upgrades, and outfits as they grow their studio and models' careers. This system provides a sense of accomplishment and an incentive to keep playing, engaging players in a loop of continuous improvement and growth.

Customization and Personalization:
[h2]HunieCam Studio offers a degree of customization and personalization[/h2]. Players can tailor the studio's layout, and the appearances and personalities of the models. This feature allows for a layer of creativity, enabling players to mold the studio to their vision.

Challenge and Strategy:
[h2]Success in HunieCam Studio[/h2] is not easily attained. Players must strategize, manage resources, and balance the models' time effectively to maximize earnings. The challenge keeps players engaged, honing their managerial skills as they strive to improve their studio's performance.

Areas for Potential Improvement:
[h2]While HunieCam Studio is entertaining[/h2], it might not appeal to everyone due to its adult-themed elements. The game's mechanics are relatively simple, and some players might desire deeper gameplay mechanics or more complex management challenges. Furthermore, players may find the game repetitive over time, as the core gameplay loop doesn't change significantly over time.

Conclusion:
[h2]HunieCam Studio offers a cheeky twist[/h2] on the management simulation genre, providing an entertaining and addictive experience. Its humor, customization options, and progression system create a delightful gameplay loop. However, the adult-themed content may deter some players, and the simplicity of the mechanics might leave others wanting more depth. For those who enjoy management sims with a touch of risqué humor and are open to the adult-themed gameplay in a light-hearted manner, HunieCam Studio might be a captivating choice. Yet, if adult themes are not appealing, there are other management simulation games available that cater to a broader audience.

This isn't the worst game you could sink time into, but it's certainly not a very good one.  As H-strategy games go, it's probably somewhere in the middle: there's decent polish put into the art and style, but the gameplay is really pretty bad.

Worst offender is the clicking.  This is not a clicker game, and doesn't play like it - but in order to do your best, you must click and hold on certain buildings to speed them up.  I'd expect that of a mobile port, but not this.  Would be far easier on the user to be able to assign a building to speed-up, and only click to change focus.

Zero keybind support that I could see - sure, "one-handed" play is an option, but there's really not much pornographic about this game.  Sure, you're commanding a camgirl business, but you never see so much as a nipple.  And while keeping one hand free is nice, as mentioned above, your mouse hand must constantly be speeding something up, so don't think you'll get to alt-tab and focus on other things.

The game itself is very straightforward, with basically no variation between runs, and no real character progression or story.  You better be good at imagining if you want to enjoy this game properly.

Sure, when it's on sale it looks like a steal - but trust me, there are far better games in this genre that are free to play, so realistically, don't bother.

In the realm of gaming, where conventional boundaries are often tested and expectations shattered, there exists a game that pushes the envelope even further, delving into the depths of human desires, societal constructs, and the nature of success itself. HunieCam Studio is a thought-provoking masterpiece that has transcended traditional gaming experiences, forever altering my perception of identity, commerce, and the illusory pursuit of achievement.

At first glance, HunieCam Studio may appear to be a mere business simulator, focusing on managing a camgirl empire. However, beneath its seemingly controversial exterior lies a profound exploration of the human condition, challenging players to question their own values and the price we are willing to pay for societal acceptance and material gain.

HunieCam Studio prompts us to reflect upon the very fabric of our society, where success is often measured by external metrics such as wealth, fame, and validation from others. As I navigated the complexities of running a camgirl enterprise, I found myself immersed in a philosophical journey that delved into the nature of identity, authenticity, and the moral implications of our choices.

The game's cast of characters embodies a diverse range of personalities, each representing different aspects of the human experience. They serve as mirrors, reflecting our own desires, fears, and the complexities of navigating societal expectations. HunieCam Studio forces us to confront our preconceived notions, challenging us to explore the depths of our own moral compass and wrestle with the ethical implications of our actions.

Beyond its controversial premise, the gameplay mechanics of HunieCam Studio are surprisingly intricate and intellectually stimulating. As players navigate the challenges of managing a camgirl empire, they are confronted with strategic decisions that prompt reflection on the nature of capitalism, exploitation, and the commodification of human relationships. It is a game that blurs the lines between personal and professional spheres, forcing us to question the boundaries of our own moral responsibility within the pursuit of success.

Visually, HunieCam Studio presents a stylized and satirical aesthetic that cleverly juxtaposes the superficial allure of the entertainment industry with the underlying moral dilemmas it encompasses. The game's colorful and bold art direction serves as a visual commentary on the often deceptive nature of success, reminding us that the pursuit of external validation can lead to a hollow existence if it comes at the cost of our integrity and authenticity.

However, it is in the game's profound message that HunieCam Studio truly shines. Through its provocative gameplay and nuanced storytelling, it serves as a poignant reminder that true success cannot be measured solely by financial gain or societal recognition. It challenges us to redefine our understanding of achievement, urging us to prioritize personal growth, self-acceptance, and the cultivation of meaningful connections over superficial markers of success.

HunieCam Studio is a gift that has irrevocably changed my perspective on identity, commerce, and the pitfalls of the pursuit of external validation. In a world where the pursuit of success can often lead us astray, HunieCam Studio stands as a provocative reminder of the importance of authenticity, ethics, and self-awareness. 138813137.review:
[h1]Short Review (Just the conclusion from the full review)[/h1]
HunieCam Studio was a solid game for a few hours, but its replayability leaves much to be desired. Every run will essentially run the same way, as once you fully figure out how to efficiently do everything, you will have no need to stray from that plan, as you will likely be punished for doing so. This is the type of game where you play it once or twice for the novelty, and then never look back. If you play it like that, then you can find enjoyment in this game, but if not, then you'll quickly discover the flaws of this game.

[h1]Full Review[/h1]
HunieCam Studio is a game that is a mixture of a management and clicker game. It acts as a sort of spin-off to the Hunie series of games while also featuring old characters from its parent game of HuniePop and some new characters that were exclusive to this game at the time of release on April 4th, 2016. 

This game lacks a story of any sort. The game starts off with your future boss greeting you saying “the legends were true” that you would eventually arrive. What that means is beyond me, as the game doesn’t elaborate on this, and throws you into the tutorials of explaining the game mechanics very quickly. However, I’ll try to explain the “story” of this game, even if it is more of a game overview, if anything. 

You're a random guy who is helping your boss who owns a cam girl business. Your job is to get girls, get money, get fans, get exposure, and not go into crippling debt for at least 21 days. If you genuinely are surprised this game doesn't have a story then you're the type of person who unironically watches porn for the plot, and that's just plain weird. 

The graphics for the girls are pretty solid in this entry of the Hunie series. I personally think that the HuniePop games tend to have characters that look a bit off, but this entry in the Hunie series rectifies all of those issues I had with the original art. The art won't blow you away, but it is pleasing enough to the eye. However, the same can't be said for graphics unrelated to the girls. Everything ELSE in the game looks like it can easily be in some cheap mobile game that tries to milk you for all you own. This doesn't necessarily mean that the graphics are horrible, but that they aren't anything spectacular, and they're mostly here out of necessity for the game to function rather than for any artistic reason.  

There are a variety of physical and personality traits that each girl has, so there is a girl for any person out there who likes girls. However, some individuals may be disappointed to hear that this game features no nudity and only has suggestive material at the most. If you were looking for a game to get you off, then look at something else, as your peepee and kitty cat probably aren't going to be leaking during this game.

The voice acting of your boss, who owns the cam girl business, is pretty good. She has a good tone, and the voice acting portrays her snarkiness and sass very well. The voice acting for the little things your cam girls say isn't outstanding, but they are a nice touch, as the developers could have easily had them have said nothing. As for the sound effects and music, they sound like they could be from a low-budget mobile game. They aren't offensive or bad, but they are just really basic.

Initially, the gameplay is surprisingly addicting and intense. It follows your standard clicker game format where you set up operations, click on them to get some arbitrary currency, and then spend them on upgrades to make your clicking more efficient.

A good trait of this game is that it is fully aware of the type of game it is. This is evident in the way your boss speaks, the descriptions of the items you use on your girls, the character bios of these girls, and more. For instance, you literally have an item that is a hard drug that allows your character to do actions faster. I'll let you take a wild guess what hard drug that is, but I won't mention it here, as hard drugs are bad, and I don't condone their usage.

Another good trait of this game is its initial intricacy. This game isn't as simple as clicking things and getting currency, but it also isn't the most amazing management game. The game does have a learning curve, as it is quite easy to go into debt if you underestimate the costs of your girls' activities. You're running a business of helping your boss legally pimp out girls of all ages, and you need to do a damn good job, or else you're done for. I actually went into too much debt on my first playthrough and needed to start over, as I didn't fully comprehend the mechanics and underestimated the game.

However, this game takes a steep drop-off in the fun department and the cracks in the gameplay start showing as you play more. As somewhat mentioned earlier, it initially had an engaging gameplay loop with lots of tiny things to micromanage and improve. It also teaches the game's various mechanics in a helpful and funny way, with your boss being quite the gem. But, after two playthroughs, I harvested most of the enjoyment I could obtain from this game, and my road to getting all achievements in the game became quite painful.

My desire not to play this game got to the point where I simply left my game open in the hard mode until the game eventually reached Day 21 on its own. This process took around 90 minutes to 120 minutes for each run, depending on what I was doing on my computer, as you need to be active on the game screen, even in windowed mode, in order to AFK the game. The truly painful part about this is that you only get eight coins per run with this strategy, and that isn't enough to even unlock all outfits/hairstyles on one character alone, so the game takes significantly longer to complete, but I can do things like writing this review or folding my laundry while watching a NileRed video while the game is running, so I feel like I'm wasting a bit less of my life on something I don't want to do.

I know my stance is biased from the lenses of an achievement hunter, but I genuinely do not care, as it would be untrue to myself to not consider this when making a review based on my experience. For a game that has an achievement where you need to replay the game multiple times in order to unlock all cosmetics, I feel like they should have been able to do a better job with replayability.

Overall, HunieCam Studio was a solid game for a few hours, but its replayability leaves much to be desired. Every run will essentially run the same way, as once you fully figure out how to efficiently do everything, you will have no need to stray from that plan, as you will likely be punished for doing so. This is the type of game where you play it once or twice for the novelty, and then never look back. If you play it like that, then you can find enjoyment in this game, but if not, then you'll quickly discover the flaws of this game.

134842114.review:
HunieCam Studio is a business sim game from the creators of HuniePop. While it’s not a bad game, it doesn’t have the same depth and amount of content as HuniePop. Instead, I think this game should be treated as a spinoff, and it’s sold cheaper as well.
This is a genre I’m not a big fan of, especially because of the real time elements. I like to take my time thinking about my next moves, so I prefer a turn-based style, like HuniePop. In here, you can pause the game and see a lot of info as well, but you have an advantage if you’re skillful using a mouse, in both precision dragging and fast clicking.
But even then, I enjoyed the game. It doesn’t have a lot of systems, but there’re a lot of different strategies you can employ. The game is designed around playing it multiple times, since a playthrough lasts around 2 hours, where the objective is to reach the highest score possible within 21 ingame days. You can continue after that, but the biggest incentive is to play again to beat your highest score, by changing your strategy. However, RNG plays a big role, especially if you’re aiming for really high scores.
Playing with self-imposed challenges is also a fun option. Achievements will require some of them, and you can also find some popular community ones. For example, playing with only a starter girl. This one severely limits your options, but you have more real-time control. Another drawback is that it relies a lot on RNG. Since the game is short, I recommend you to play in different ways, it definitely makes the game more enjoyable.
Beating the game will net you tokens, that you can use to unlock costumes and hairstyles for the girls. That’s the only thing that carries over between playthroughs. Beating the game also unlocks a hard mode, with a lot of changes that you must find yourself. It really ups the difficulty, but makes the game way more stressful to play in my opinion. I prefer trying different strategies and challenges in the normal difficulty.
While the game is mostly a HuniePop coat paint on the genre, there’s no real adult content in here. The activities reflect you managing an adult business, and all the original main girls for HuniePop are present, some with significant changes though. The art style and music are decent enough.
Even if this is not as good as HuniePop, it’s still a solid game. I had a good time, and I’m not a fan of the genre. The gameplay loop works well here, since playthroughs are short and allow you to try different stuff each time. Definitely a good option on sale.

This is actually an amazing game design. The game play is a complex puzzle where you have to navigate between managing time, gathering resources and purchasing upgrades. How efficient you are this determines your final score and purchasing the right upgrades early in the game are important to maximizing your score. 

To get a really high score you will need a strategy. There are quite a few that people have come up with that will work. Once you have strategy you then you have execute successfully. 

The game is extremely fast paced; it is a RACE and requires a large amount of focus and concentration. In that respect the game in engaging and fun but it's NOT laid back and relaxing at all. This NOT A CASUAL GAME. It can even feel a little stressful as you are racing to gather your resources and purchase that next best upgrade. 

I find the design quite brilliant and stimulating but maybe not for the faint of heart.

112115649.review:
This review is based on Gameplay, Story, Graphics, Steam Achievements and other noteworthy details.

Gameplay:
Simple to understand, you can pick it up within the first 15 minutes or less, but thinking up tactics will take a little longer. This game is a clicking game; the use of a keyboard isn't necessary at all. You can click and drag characters to do their tasks, hold down your mouse to "auto-click" or manually click as quickly as you can (it hurts!). It takes a few tries of the game but because there is a lack of a story, you can consider this game a casual game.

Story:
There isn't really one. More like a rough description that you're put in charge to manage a camgirl studio and you're supposed to get as much fans/followers for the studio as you can within 21 days. The goal is pretty straight forward and the game is still very fun without the story. This kind of casualness makes the game have loads of replay value, in that you're replaying either to beat your own high score or get some achievements.

Graphics:
Simple, nothing that needed 3d rendering. Pretty much 2d; but cute designs. Cute girls too. I have a crush on Nora; she's what I want to be. But anyway; not much to say about graphics. It runs smoothly on my laptop; but I don't suppose it needs a lot.

Achievements:
Hardest: Diamond D-Train
Easiest: Entrepreneur
So I've played this game on and off for about 4 years and I only recently started putting in any effort to get the achievements. Diamond D-Train and Wolf of Ball Skeet were the hardest achievements to get for me. I managed after many tries to get Wolf of Ball Skeet on my own but needed the help of a Youtube Playthrough to see how to get Diamond D-train...after that it took about 4 more tries before I finally got the trophy!
You'll definitely need to play the game through more than three times to get the trophies but I can assure you, it gets easier each time!

Other:
I haven't played Huniepop yet but I will be playing that next, apparently this is a stand alone game and doesn't require players to have played Huniepop first.
Obviously isn't a game suitable for kids, but you know; if you needed to be told that, you probably shouldn't be parenting. 
Each 21 day cycle is a game. It takes about an hour and a half to complete a 21 day cycle before your game ends with a tally of scores. You can quit halfway through a game and return to it later.
No nudity but very lewd. I like.
Has humour and doesn't take itself too seriously. There's an achievement called "disappoint your parents".
No bugs or anything but once (and this could be something else entirely but) my game blacked out; no sound, no visuals so I just shut down the game and restarted it.
Have fun! I highly recommend it! 
8/10

111127271.review: Honestly, one of the most genuinely fun MMOs I've ever played. Solid game. Fun combat, good questing system, and there is a various selection of classes to choose from. 3-player dungeons can be played with friends and you can have a subclass which I find very unique and the eidolons are very cool as well since they act like pets that actually aid you in battle. The customization for your character is also not bad as you can equip cosmetics and create how your character looks with basic character customization upon character creation. The use of mounts and portals is also a very good way for fast travel. I also like how you can simply select your quest and you can automatically go to your desired destination with a route that is closest to your objective. If you are ever lost on the quest line, you can always check the map for an orange exclamation mark (!) and simply click on it to travel there. Overall, very solid game, very few issues, I would recommend playing this game. Ignore all of the negative reviews, they don't know what they're talking about. If your friends don't want to play with you, I'd say screw them and play by yourself as it won't make that much of a difference besides the 10% XP boost and optional 3-player dungeons.

After how much I liked HuniePop, I was so looking forward to this sequel. Sadly, this one lacks all of the charm and fun puzzle elements of its predecessor, opting to replace them with mobile game-esque time sinks. 

You recruit girls to do cam shows and photo shoots. Each girl has different talents and things she does. Fine, with you so far.

A single cam show takes 12 hours. That doesn't sound right to me.
Resources don't collect on their own without purchasing a powerup in the shop tab, called "Invest" here.
The goal is to gain fans. Every time you put a girl in the photo shoot building, you gain fans. But you have to collect them just like everything else, and without upgrading your girls extensively, you get perhaps 50 fans per shoot. 
Oh, and the shoots take something like 7 hours.

You're given 21 in-game days to fulfill these goals. Every night at midnight, the girls take payroll, and the amount seems to be arbitrary. One night, they took over $4,000 from me, the next night they took half that. Not sure what that's about.

Every activity takes way too long to do, and then collecting your rewards on top of that takes almost as long. And with such a strict time limit on play, that's not fun.

The new girls also are awful. Terrible voices, terrible designs. I'll stick with HuniePop and maybe try HuniePop 2. This one ain't for me.

The game is crude/ecchi in nature but with mostly safe artwork and high quality characters/voice acting etc.

The gameplay is a management game with a hectic time limit that can be ignored but is the main challenge for score setting including 5 baked in thresholds that you'll need to overcome to unlock some achievements. It incorporates clicker elements but you can hold on buildings instead while still being possible to beat the game. It looks great, feels great and plays great. The tutorial is clear on everything while leaving the interactivity of each element for you to consider, making it a fun puzzle to get your head round.

Your cam business starts off very slowly as the first 2 recruiting rounds are guaranteed to not produce girls with overlapping attributes forcing you to balance photoshoots (which earn fans) and camshows (which earn cash per related fan). Or you can keep recruiting girls until you have a good combination that can earn fans for the other, or load the girls up with the same accessories once the shop unlocks (skipping the tutorial on subsequent playthroughs unlocks all buildings immediately). The rest of the game is spent unlocking investments and optimising your setup. 

The 21 game days takes probably an hour or so to reach each game. Along with the 5 score thresholds there are a few achievements to occupy the player, plus a hard mode and styles/costumes to unlock. It's the sort of game that holds my attention intensely and has done for a few days, but after about a week I will probably not find reason to play again. The price is worth it for that time I think.

Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Simulation game.


[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]


[quote][b]Video Settings information.[/b][/quote]


[list]
    [*]There aren't many resolution sizes available and they start off on 1024 x 576. From there it only goes higher.
    [*]You can enforce the 16:9 ratio.
    [*]You can play the game fullscreen or windowed mode.
    [*]There is no other graphical settings available  
    [*]There is no color blind mode.
[/list]

[quote][b]Volume Settings information.[/b][/quote]

[list]
    [*]You are able to change the music volume with a slidebar. It has no Percentage.
    [*]You are able to change the sound volume with a slidebar. It has no Percentage.
    [*]You are able to change the voice volume with a slidebar. It has no Percentage.
    [*]There is no instant mute button.
[/list]

[quote][b]Keyboard Controls / Controller / VR Information.[/b][/quote]

[list]
    [*]You can only play the game with your mouse.
    [*]It has no mouse sensitivity.
[/list]

[quote][b]Miscellaneous Information.[/b][/quote]

[list]
    [*]There is no difficulty.
    [*]English language only.
    [*]There are 6 different save / profile slots.
    [*]The option menu hasn't a lot to offer.
[/list]


[h1]About the game.[/h1]

Before i am going to be explain and share the information with you about the game. There is absolutely NO nudity in this game at all. No Nudity patches either!

This is a short but relaxing simulation game were you are constantly dragging girl head icons into buildings to let them do activities.  There are about 18 girls and each of them has their own game style.
Some are wearing glasses, some are smokers, some are drinkers, some has some big bonkers, some has big booty, different races and skin colors. 

You will start off by choosing 1 girl out of the 3 (like choosing your first pokemon in a pokemon game) and each of them has a different style. After you have picked a girl you will have to move her to the photo booth so she is able to gain fans, then move her to the Cam studio to give you some cash.

A girl will make more money the more fans she has. You are able to equip or give her accessories which could increase her fan base, other female's fan base, reducing shopping time, condoms for safe but quick money and a few others.
Shopping to get booze or smokes are for free but they do require time. They are important to have as some girls could be drinkers or smokers or both and if you have ran out they will be stressed out quicker.

Each time a girl is doing an activity they will build up stress and you will have to send them to the SPA to let them relax. 
You can send one of your workers to a model center to gain a new random worker and you can buy ads to increase the fan base of a specific fetish.

You are able to upgrade one of your investments to earn more money, have more workers, gain more fans, reduce waiting time and a few other things. You can also train your workers and increase their earning on Cam studios or photo booths but their payment will be increased too. If you are in debt for 24 hour (So at the next 12:00 pm), you are game over and will be forced to restart over.

If you have managed to survive and complete 21 days you will see your score and get some tokens. The tokens can be spend on the wardrobe (on the main menu) so a girl will have a different clothes or hair style appearance but will have no game effect. Once you have bought all of the hair styles and clothes you will unlock a personal photo from her (NO NUDITY) were she is doing a pose.

[quote][b] (Shorter) in-game Information.[/b][/quote]

[list]
    [*]There are no cutscenes.
    [*]The graphics are simple and barely has any emotions.
    [*]The game is automatically paused when the screen is not focused.
    [*]Text dialog is slow but you are able to skip them. You could instantly display the text by clicking a few times.
    [*]Game is relaxing and is not stressing you out.
    [*]Game is purely simulation and barely any real management.
    [*]Text dialog is voiced over.
    [*]There is an ingame tutorial.
    [*]Short game as you have completed the game in 21 Days, you can still continue after or restart over.
    [*]There are options ingame.
    [*]You can manually save and load the game.
    [*]You are able to unlock hard mode.
[/list]

[quote][b]Miscellaneous Information.[/b][/quote]

[list]
    [*]The game has no nudity and there is no nudity patch either.
    [*]The game has achievements.
    [*]Game has an ironic price tag of 6,99. I do wait for a discount or buy the game in a bundle.
    [*]The game has 9 steam cards and 5 of them can be found as a drop.
[/list]

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

This game is pretty easy to understand and quite short. I have only played this game twice and i have managed to get the (highest) Diamond trophy (100k fans) within 102 minutes in my second run. Game isn't too difficult and skipping the tutorials will only have sped up my process.

My first run was more of a practice round but it was hardly needed. There is nothing cute about the game either so don't be too fooled.. 95% of the time you are only moving head icons to buildings to let them perform activities. The other 5% is opening their inventory to equip items.

While i do admit, i hate sex games on steam since they are LITERALLY ALL OVER THE GAMING PLATFORM WITH NO QUALITY OR EFFORT. i do like sexual activities. This game doesn't have it but that doesn't mean i do love/hate the game.

The game is not addicting even tho it may feel addicting if you are playing a round. You are constantly doing busy things with little to no breaks in between and before you know it the game is already over.

The game forces you to constantly pay attention as there is a time limit that is constantly running (except when a menu is open) and you have a goal to achieve by the end. You can argue this is a good thing because most clicker games are not engaging and run by themselves, but a time limit doesn't make the gameplay more fun or interesting, just more stressful. 94864927.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 34.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. the hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, also 4 years old. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you, Huniecam Studio.

85176492.review:
If I have a guilty pleasure game, this is one of two. Only, instead of exploiting my gambling problem and stubbornness, this game exploits [i]horny[/i] and [i]monkey brain like big number[/i]. 

[b]GAMEPLAY INFO[/b]
You're a pimp, you hire sexy and girls with unique, but not notably deep, personalities (and customizable outfits and hairstyles). The girls you hire can do photo shoots for fans, or cam shows for money; your final score is based on fans and fans effect your income, and everything else in the game is based on money, time or people. You manage your girls as they do things- cam shows, shopping for "accessories" which grant benefits, training to be better at cam shows and photo shoots, shopping for addictions, etc., while managing their stress levels, trying to stay out of debt (you gotta pay your girls), and trying to gain fans.
Basically, it's a clicker game (but not an idle game) on a time limit, about 3 hours to play through in my experience, but you'll wanna play through multiple times to try to get a better rank. The game's difficulty options come in the form of two difficulty settings, and different rankings depending on how well you do, with the minimum goal of the game being to not go bankrupt, and the maximum being to unlock the higher difficulty and get the platinum dick trophy (I am not being serious but I am being honest). Additionally, with each playthrough you unlock tokens, with tokens you buy new outfits and hair styles for each girl, and upon getting all the options for any given girl you get a special photo of that girl (these photos are sometimes used for loading screens as well, even without unlocking them); this provides a secondary objective, for the completionests out there.
The game has nice depth to it, with the management/clicker gameplay being quite enjoyable. It's not an idle game, and you're always focused on something. Managing addictions, stress, money and STDs add a counterbalance to the game, and the game provides a good array of options for how you handle and strategize things, with luck and stubbornness playing into it at times and making you ask yourself whether or not it's worth taking a risk. All in all, good gameplay, available in nice sized chunks with a number of objectives.

[b]PRESENTATION[/b]
I wouldn't call this "fan service." After all, it's somewhat the blatant point of the game, to be at all coy about it seems silly to me. It's a sexual game, about sexual things with light pornographic content. It's not a game I'd likely jerk off to, but that's more a comment on the "light" part of "light pornography," rather than a comment of quality.
The art is good- cutesy with a bit of pop to it, almost chibi like in nature? I don't know, describing this stuff ain't my strong suit, but I can testify to the quality of it, including the art of the characters. Like I said, light pornography at most, but still very sexy- and even if a given character doesn't fit your fetish, the art is still enjoyable.

[b]UI, BUGS & ETC.[/b]
Never have I encountered any serious bugs, nor can I recall ever encountering minor ones. The UI, menus and shortcuts and the like are all good, although not quite perfect, with good audio to accompany them. I've not tried modding, although I actually plan to right after writing this review.

[b]CLOSING[/b]
I wouldn't recommend this game to my sex repulsed asexuals of course, or to that one guy on reddit who struggled with the HuniePop due to struggling with the idea of cheating on any of the girls, but I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun clicker game or some good light hentai.
For my pure feelings? I very much like, dare I say love the game, and it has easily been worth the money I spent buying it.

83999947.review:
I played HuniePop, which is by the same company. I enjoyed that game, it was a decent action puzzle/dating sim fusion, and seeing this, I had fresh expectations... But it didn't deliver like I hoped.

It was not by any means a definitively "bad" game, like I would not hit the No recommend button. The craftsmanship in the graphics and voice acting and all are there and that's beautifully done, thus that's what I praise about this game. It's definitely a refreshing change from the stereotypical anime look, and the voices filling in made me appreciate the characters (the same ones from HuniePop) as the company's very own cast I expect to be used again and again from time to time. I feel like that alone saved the rest of the game for me.

Where this game falls apart is the game design itself; a perfect example of how excellently-made media doesn't determine a good and engaging game. This had a metric ton of potential to be a solid erotic-themed business simulator and it fell apart by being a simplistic 21-day (in-game) numbers race, with nothing really left to accomplish after the fact. And your wrist will hurt more by clicking the mouse to rage-collect things on time, than what you imagine a game like this is supposed to be for. Besides that, you aren't really getting to ogle the girls, you're looking at the overhead of a town, and getting more of the intended "pleasure" from the voice-acting or bare-bone imagining yourself as the manager of a group of camgirls.

They could have even revamped the idea of just being centered around camgirls. It could have very easily been a full-blown brothel or strip-club (or some other kind/mix of sex establishment) simulator. Clients to follow up on, expand your business empire, get into films, cast talent, make the audience metrics even more useful than just collecting fans to earn more money, negotiate, control turf, put out business cards, so on and so forth, you go wild with your imagination.

I suppose you can argue that it's an erotic game and there's no point in expecting a major quality product from something like this, but I feel like it didn't have to be this lightweight. My thing is, it could have been so, so much better, and one part of it dragged the good parts down with it.

I did hit the Yes recommend because I'm not against buying it and wouldn't tell others otherwise... But I'd say hold out and wait for a really heavy sale on it instead if you want to add it to your Steam Erotica collection; because you're basically looking at an overglorified timesink-style phone app for the PC and there really isn't much in the game. I got it when it was like 90% off (around $1) or something. That's justifiably small enough for this.

73208013.review:
This game caught my attention some time ago because it's one of the many "managers" on Steam and has a very good rating by users, I decided to try it after being on a huge discount just another times. Let's put it straight for little boys, there's a lack of nudity, but there's a lack of gameplay too, it wasn't the manager or tycoon I was expecting, but gave me a decent amount of fun for it's discounted price. It's more like a one-try challenge with the highest score you can achieve, focusing  on interesting mechanics in a dark background like the cam world.


[b][u]PROS[/u][/b]
[list]

[*][u]GRAPHICS[/u]: Nothing special and looking like what it truly is, a flash game, but pleasant after all with decent drawings, the lack of nudity makes it more user friendly, but there's not much more to mention about it. It lacks of 1080p, not very acceptable for a PC only 2016 game, I chose to play it windowed.

[*][u]MANAGING MECHANICS[/u]: The managing mechanics are simple but interesting, you will hire girls, pay wages based on their worktime, find objects for bonuses, manage investments to raise your earnings, decide between let girls earn money or make them boost stats and more; Once you understand mechanics, you'll have to rely on a little of luck too, just to make the run more interesting. There's not too much to learn, you have to find the right balancement or trick to make your way through known problems, if it was too easy, there's a play hard mode which basically triples girls salaries to make your money tighter.

[*][u]ADDICTING[/u]: I won't deny it, it was very addicting at the beginning, after a bad first run, I was finally learning mechanics on my own mistakes and couldn't wait to improve run by run, until I finally reached the highest trophy after many tries. Unless you are so good to beat it easily on the first run or have no interest in achievements, it will keep you stuck playing it until you reach your goal.

[*][u]ACHIEVEMENTS[/u]: While the game has no real goal inside, achievements are the true goals to focus on and keep playing it. I considered them essential to give myself a reason to play the game, because its basic mechanic is really too simple. Achieving them all is not impossible and not too hard.

[*][u]DISCOUNTS[/u]: I have had this game in my wishlist for a long time and I was tempted to buy it several times, because it is on huge discount very often. You can usually buy it for a good price: a mere dollar.

[*][u]MUSIC[/u]: Nothing special but worth a mention, smooth soundtrack made of 3 tracks, sweetly faded and mixed depending by the in game time: That's a good alarm just in case you forget to check the time and midnight is approaching.

[/list]


[b][u]CONS[/u][/b]
[list]

[*][u]FLASH GAME?[/u]: The best way to describe my discomfort is to call it a mediocre flash game. Don't get me wrong, I love flash games and they are quite addicting with their funny style, but I was looking for something different on sale on steam. The game is extremely simple and gives you the feeling of flash game emptiness, the new game is a limited time challenge, there are better flash games for free.

[*][u]GAMEPLAY[/u]: Maybe I wasn't the real target of this game, but I disliked the idea of a 21-days run with a final score, your only goal (beside not going negative for over 24 hours) is to achieve the highest score, then retry to make it better, unless you aim to get Steam's achievements. I was expecting a better tycoon/manager game, with a better replayability and a post-end continuation (you can keep playing your save after the 21 days limit, but the game already turned into a boring click spam). Better goals or better modes could make it more enjoyable after the first tries, thankfully achievements are a bit more challenging and there's a hard mode to raise difficulty.

[*][u]LONGEVITY[/u]: Very addicting after the first couple runs, kind of boring after you acknowledge its mechanics to improve your score and aim to achievements. Replayability is very low and each run starts becoming boring, just like a flash game

[*][u]PRICE[/u]: Its full price is 7€ (~8$), the game is not worth that much, there's really nothing special to make it different of a free flash game, I wouldn't recommend it for its full price  at all. 

[/list]

Final word: Basically a flash game made of 21 days runs with highest score milestones, some simple but addicting managing mechanics, decent art but lacks of goals and replayability. Only recommended because, after all, it works decently and entertained me for more hours than expected, not recommended at its full price but discounts are frequent.

If you're a HuniePop Fan you'll like this game. I'm not a fan of time management games in general, but I enjoy it enough to keep trying for all the achievements. It is VERY challenging. Difficult, in fact. It's a 21 day run and takes about 2hrs to play through. HunieCam Studio is a good solid game with replay value, even if it is kind of seedy. 

UPDATE--Since the release of HuniePop2, I've got really mixed feelings about the whole HP franchise. HCS has some humor and characterizations that felt a little off to me when I first played this game. I'm a big fan of dirty/offensive humor like that found in TV shows such as Family guy and Big Mouth. I figured that any little gags or gimmicks I found to be offensive or close to it were just a sign that I'm starting to get old. 

HCS is pretty raunchy, and many of the girls are portrayed as fairly obnoxious. I also found earning the "Collect all 6 STDs in one game" achievement pretty much the limit of bad taste. (It doesn't help that it practically broke my heart when Tiffany got HIV.) But I told myself, "dude, for a guy who likes Archer and American Dad you're kind of being a wuss." 

However, the recent release of HP2 has me reevaluating whether it is all innocent, over-the-top humor or something more. HP2 repeatedly uses several vocabulary words belonging to the Alt-Right political movement. Once I noticed that I had to question whether it really is boundary pushing humor meant all in good fun, or the Devs' political and social values quietly being slipped into these games.

Mentioning my concerns over some of the humor and word choices got me called every dirty bigoted name the Steam Fanboi Army could think of, so I'm totally over trying to even discuss it. These are good quality games, but seriously... If the guy whose screen name is "Deez Nuts" thinks your game is legit offensive, maybe just maybe you should take it seriously.

71999232.review:
[h1] An Unexpectedly Enjoyable Game [/h1] 
It was a lonely, cold night when I was browsing the Summer Sales of 2020 on Steam - searching for something, or someone to comfort me through my sadness. Eagerly awaiting warmth. Upon scrolling through endless pages... I finally came across HunieCam Studio and the cute yet seductive smiles that the girls had on their pretty faces. I purchased the game without hesitation but I didn't have high expectations. It feels as if nothing can warm my sad lonely heart up nowadays. Depressing story aside, HunieCam Studio is much better than I thought it'd be. 

[h1] Positives [/h1] 
[b] Graphics [/b] 
Although the game doesn't include many animations as such, the drawings themselves are very cute and great quality. The graphics look great on my screen and the girls all look fine!

[b] Easy to Play [/b] 
The fact that there's a tutorial makes it easy to play through and learn. Some games don't have tutorials so... yeah it is useful. It's an easy game to understand and fun to play when you need to kill time. 

[b] Wardrobe Items [/b] 
You can farm different outfits and hairstyles for each girl - however it does take a while... which makes it extremely painful if you're going for the achievement. I like how the outfits suit each individual and their characteristics. 

[b] Diversity [/b] 
HunieCam allows you to employ a diverse range of girls from different ethnic backgrounds which is nice to see! There ar other characteristics you that girls have such as; flat chest, big boobs, fit and chubby. Can literally hire black girls, white girls, skinny girls, fat girls... 

[b] Achievements [/b] 
Achievement hunters will like this game, the achievements are relatively easy to unlock. The hardest one however is the one that requires you to unlock all of the outfits. Quite grindy to get that one. 

[h1] Negatives [/h1] 
[b] Short Game [/b] 
The actual game itself doesn't take very long to complete and there isn't much reason to replay unless it's for achievements or something. There isn't that much incentive to keep playing a file further than the 21 day mark. You won't get that much gameplay out of it.

[b] Could Improve a Few Things [/b] 
The developers could improve the game by introducing different campaign lengths such as short (21 days), medium (28 days) and long (35 days). That way people could play longer or shorter game modes and get more wardrobe tokens within one save file. 

More content could be added to the adult shop such as video tapes, ropes, whips, waifu pillows - idk, get creative. Introduce more things to do in the game, more buildings, just more of everything. 

[h1] Conclusion [/h1] 
At the end of the day, the game was cheap and definitely worth the money and the laughs. The positives outweigh the negatives so if you want a game to kill time then you can. This game is $2 when on sale and worth buying if you enjoy achievements and sexci girls.

71670134.review:
So I've played six games and I'll be honest, it feels like one step forward and two steps back. Now I'm judging the base game but this is in summary how I feel.

They took the best part about cam girls, and made it into something great. The best part being the wardrobe and aesthetic. What made HunieCam studio so good? The early game is peoples first instinct perhaps, "maybe just one more girl", but I'd argue that Hunie recognized a core flaw in micro-managing gaming, pacing. Most games start out interesting, establish girls, roles and just sorta farm from there. There's usualy a twist in there when first starting, but that twist played off after the fourth run.

In HunieCam Studio you started off very focused on expansion and revenue. Only really concerned with the immediate wage/payroll. Then it became your empire and your home. Once you got money, more girls, higher stats, perhaps a few STDs. Then the snowball happens, you can make and grow your empire rapidly. So you start investing, and all of a sudden everyone is making bank. Promos become more expensive, and you're competing for them mostly non violently. By the end of the game, every girl is in a strategic location, and you no longer are just concerned with your immediate threats from the beginning, you have bigger goals that you have the reach for the endgame.

In HunieCam, the girls made you give it all and also made it so you no longer had a reason to invest in what made you download the game. HunieCam is like a bad good board game. It's all about looking at what you're doing and only worrying about what others do if it affects your internal planning. It's all about maximizing girls, not going "Oh, I should probably ally Lillian and Tiffany because best girl... And that other girls cant rival or can't have that." Or "I need to make sure I have Audrey and Nadia because simps online tell me to!"

As result, you never really care what's going on in the world, or who you're recruiting. And it causes the whole game to kinda melt together. If you honestly asked me what's the difference between the early game, and the late game, I would hesitantly say Matt's mom lookalikes and best girls. The truth is, HunieCam made you feel like history was changing as you played it, changing the gameplay and how you interacted with the world. HunieCam feels like a game of dominion, where I optimize my economy and hope nobody interupts me. It doesn't feel like a journey through history, I can hardly feel a difference between mid and late game. And I think that's a big shame. It's a great game, 9/10 would nut again.

If you look like any of the girls in the game, hit me up. Looking for e-girlfriend

70370878.review:
I'm a big fan of HunieCam Studio. My normal record is 505k and my rockhard record is 133k, so it's fair to say that I know the game very well. I have also played HuniePop a great deal, and I can confidently confirm that HunieCam Studio has much more depth in terms of gameplay strategy. Whereas HuniePop fizzles out at the end with key date gift combos that you use the same way every time, HunieCam Studio constantly evolves as you discover new ways to beat your high score. The game also features a good amount of RNG to make each run different.

The only complaint that I have with the game is the "finger-blasting" rapid clicking that can be faster than holding down LMB. Since this is a click-farm game, and a run easily takes one and a half to two hours, it can feel like your hand is going to break off at the end of a play session. My advice for this is simply to hold down LMB instead of rapidly clicking. In my experience, core strategy gets you much much farther anyway, and my high scores did not involve any rapid clicking. I've spoken to some of the other major players in the meta (there are like five of us who play this game competitively with each other, please join us in the HuniePot discord), and they seem to agree that finger-blasting doesn't make a significant difference when you're going for the really high scores. Especially when there are gameplay strategies out there that nobody has cracked yet.

I watched Jacksepticeye play this game before buying it myself. I love games where you have to manage your own store/city, so I decided to try it out despite its...theme. But aside from the theme, the game is pretty fun.
The premise of the game is that you're in charge of a cam girl studio. The goal is to get as many fans as possible by sending the girls to work, improving their skills, buying promos and so on. The more fans you have at the end of the game, the greater your award is.
The artstyle is pretty cute, and I like how you can expand the characters' wardrobe (Hairstyles + outfits) with the coins you get after completing the game.
And even though you have to keep your business going for 21 days, those days pass by rather quickly. I took me less than 2 hours to complete one run (Then again, I did watch Jack play the game before this, so I already knew how everything worked and could just skip the entire tutorial).
But just so you know, the game isn't very story rich. And there's no direct interaction/dialogues with the girls either with an exception for the tutorial.
I might give it another try some other day to see if I can beat my score, but I'm not interested in replaying the game at the moment.
Would recommend this game to adults who like management games and/or the people who - unlike me - actually are the targetted audience.

61333410.review:
Hunnie Cam Studio is the spin off game to the great HuniePop game. They are similar in some aspects like it deals with girl management but with a twist. It is more like a timed based simulation where you are trying to maximize your fans within a strict time limit. I will be reviewing the game in a pro/ con style and end with my conclusion.

Pro:
     The gameplay is simple. Mainly your goal is to balance both money gained through girls streaming and the fans you get. The thing that is the most useful thing when playing is building up your fans which can be earned with photos, buying ads, or to a degree streaming. The fans help you gain more money per show and are the thing that grants you a trophy at the end if you hit a specific milestone.

      Tons of replay value. Now the gameplay does not really change but since recruiting girls is very random as to who you get can really make each run through the game different and there are many combinations of girls to synergize with but also items to equip. Eventually it will get to the point of trying to beat your high score and get the highest trophy which is not easy.

        There are alot of customizable outfits for the girls. Some ranging from ok but the later ones are the really spicy ones. The only way to get those are by unlocking trophies which grants the player some points to unlock cosmetics like a new hair style for a specific girl or a costume. 

Con:
      The game compared to their previous project is tame. This is a warning to those with expectation for having the idea that this game is anywhere spicy as the previous game or contain an uncensored version. It does not so do not go into the game looking for that type of content. That is something that does not subtract from the game itself in any stretch of the imagination but to warn people of their expectations from going from huniepop to hunie cam.

Conclusion:
       HunieCam is a great game. It is a bit more challenging that HuniePop's match 3 system which didnt take much skills. Managing which job is best suited for each girl or managing when to invest or purchase promo's. Since it is a limited time given to the player which is 21 days in game for them to manage their studio of girls in hopes to gain a huge fan base like 100k for the highest trophy does ask for a lot of planning. I recommend the game as a good time waster since it does not offer much in terms of either gameplay or story but it is pretty good dumb fun and it is hard to hate on dumb fun.

And that's not realllly the best representation of how things go nowadays but hey, I didn't come in here expecting realism and I can appreciate the added risk in the game. Anyway, you can avoid it by stocking up on condoms or skipping the escort option entirely. 

There's a timed campaign (about 2.5 hrs real time) where you try to gain as many fans as possible to earn trophies and unlock wardrobe items, but you can continue playing your save file after that point if you want. I like the time limit because it gives me an easy stopping point, and I suspect I'd otherwise get stuck in this game for wayyyy too long at a time. But my biggest complaint is that there are no goals to aim for except number of fans - it doesn't encourage experimenting with different play styles. There are a small handful of steam achievements, but no in-game reward for them, so if you want to unlock wardrobe items you need to maximize fans only, and I think that will get boring eventually. I'd love to get little trophies/wardrobe points for reaching a certain amount of revenue, or for earning enough through escort services for example. Even if there was just one or two wardrobe points added for every Steam achievement you reach, it'd be cool.

Long story short: very fun and nicely done, definitely worth its sale price, but would like to see more goals than just "as many fans as possible" to keep things interesting.
